title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information on commercial alien smuggling organizations. Nonimmigrant aliens with critical reliable information on commercial alien smuggling organizations may be allowed to stay in the United States if deemed essential by the Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General. Nonimmigrant aliens with critical reliable information on commercial alien smuggling organizations may be allowed to stay in the United States if deemed essential by the Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General for authorized criminal investigations or disrupting such organizations. Nonimmigrant aliens involved in commercial alien smuggling organizations may be allowed to stay in the US for authorized criminal investigations or disrupting such organizations, as determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act limits the number of nonimmigrants under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) to 400 per fiscal year. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General can determine the identity of nonimmigrants involved in commercial alien smuggling organizations. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General can take lawful action to protect the identity of nonimmigrants under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new provisions for nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) who provide specific information. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) if they provide information that substantially contributes to a commercial alien smuggling investigation, operation disruption, or prosecution. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of certain aliens and their family members to that of lawful permanent residents, as long as they are not described in section 212(a)(3)(E). This adjustment applies to nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) who have contributed significantly to a commercial alien smuggling investigation. The Secretary of Homeland Security can adjust the status of certain aliens and their family members to lawful permanent residents, excluding those described in section 212(a)(3)(E). This adjustment applies to nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) who have aided in a commercial alien smuggling investigation. Additionally, if the identity of a person being adjusted must be protected, officials can take necessary lawful actions for protection. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act may be increased by up to 10 years for individuals who bring aliens into the United States in violation of the law, under certain conditions. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for increased criminal penalties of up to 10 years for individuals who transport groups of 10 or more aliens in a way that endangers their lives or poses a health risk. Additionally, a rewards program is established in the Department of Homeland Security to incentivize the enforcement of this section. A rewards program is established in the Department of Homeland Security to assist in eliminating commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens in a way that endangers their lives or poses a health risk. The rewards program established by the Department of Homeland Security aims to combat commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens that endanger lives or pose health risks. The program is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, who may authorize rewards at their discretion. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay rewards to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives, aiding or abetting such acts, or preventing them. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling, including the prevention, frustration, or dismantling of smuggling operations, and identifying key leaders in such operations. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling operations, including identifying key leaders who endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this subsection. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards for information on commercial alien smuggling operations that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose, and certain government officials are ineligible for rewards if they provide such information in the course of their official duties. Protection measures may be implemented by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Protection measures may be taken by the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, or the Attorney General to safeguard the identity of individuals providing information on commercial alien smuggling operations. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary of State, or Attorney General can take lawful action to protect the identity of individuals providing information on alien smuggling operations, with a maximum reward of $100,000 unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize rewards exceeding $100,000 to combat alien smuggling operations endangering lives or presenting life-threatening situations. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize rewards exceeding $50,000 for the transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more that endanger lives or pose a life-threatening health risk. Any reward exceeding $50,000 requires personal approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security and certification for payment. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize rewards exceeding $50,000 for the transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more that endanger lives or pose a life-threatening health risk. Any reward granted under this subsection shall be certified for payment by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Additionally, an outreach program will be developed to educate the public in the United States and abroad about immigration laws. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in smuggling investigations.
